author: alx9r
body:
I'm not sure if this is by design or not, but the behavior is surprising to me.  `InitialSessionState.CreateDefault().ExecutionPolicy` seems to be `Restricted`.  This means that whenever `Runspace.Open()` is called with an `InitialSessionState` based on `InitialSessionState.CreateDefault()` the _calling_ runspace's (nb. not just the newly-opened runspace's) ExecutionPolicy is changed to `Restricted`.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
$originalPolicy = Get-ExecutionPolicy
$originalPolicy

$otherPolicy = if ( $originalPolicy -eq 'Bypass' )
{
    [Microsoft.PowerShell.ExecutionPolicy]::Restricted
}
else
{
    [Microsoft.PowerShell.ExecutionPolicy]::Bypass
}

$initialSessionState = [initialsessionstate]::CreateDefault()
$initialSessionState.ExecutionPolicy = $otherPolicy

[runspacefactory]::CreateRunspace($initialSessionState).Open()

Get-ExecutionPolicy
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

I expected `ExecutionPolicy` to be the same before and after `Runspace.Open()`

```none
RemoteSigned
RemoteSigned
```

Actual behavior
---------------

`ExecutionPolicy` is changed to `InitialSessionState.ExecutionPolicy`.

```none
RemoteSigned
Bypass
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.688
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.688
OS                             Microsoft Windows 6.3.9600
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: alx9r
comments.body: @iSazonov I see.  That seems like a reasonable implementation of default behavior to me.  I'm more concerned that opening another runspace with that default also changes the execution policy of the runspace that opened it.  That seems like a side-effect that shouldn't happen.

comments.author: mattpwhite
comments.body:
The relevant line seems to be - https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/69bf7043c0c7471679265778e12053c1c40b0000/src/System.Management.Automation/security/SecuritySupport.cs#L169, not the one @iSazonov quoted above (though the statement about being global is correct).  Setting the execution policy simply sets a process-scope environment variable, affecting all runspaces.  That process scope env var takes precedence over any non-GPO execution policy (and is not cached anywhere, the environment gets parsed each time it needs to be checked, not sure exactly how often that happens, but it's not free).

Changing this behavior would probably be considered breaking, so I guess that's out of the question.  Intuitively it does seem like it should be a property of the Runspace/SessionState (at least in the form of allowing the runspace to have "Default" inherit from the process, but allow for it to be overridden per Runspace).

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: ... @PaulHigin is it possible that this is a security issue? Seems a bit unsettling at best that every new runspace opened changes the _current_ runspace's execution policy...

title: The current runspace's ExecutionPolicy is overridden by InitialSessionState.ExecutionPolicy of a newly-opened runspace
